Some notes about the speaker: Dexter Perkins is the John L. Senior Pro¬
fessor of American Civilization at Cornell University, with a distinguished
reputation as diplomatic historian and university teacher in many countries.
He went to Cornell in 1952 from the University of Rochester, where he had
been Professor of History since 1915 and Chairman of the Department of His-
sory since 1925. He was the first American to occupy the Pitt Chair at
Cambridge University, in 19ii5-lt6, and lectured at the University of.Uppsala,
Sweden, in 19h9; the University of London; the Defence College in Kingston,
Ontario, Canada; Johns Hopkins and Harvard Universities; the National War
College; and the Naval War College. He is Chairman of the Harvard Founda¬
tion for Advanced Study and Research, is on the Board of Overseers of Har¬
vard University, and is President of the Salzburg (Austria) Seminar on
American Studies, The Salzburg Seminar was opened in 19^7 to help make
Americans known to Europeans; its professors are American, its participants
are European. Professor Perkins went to Salzburg in 19U9 and has been
President of the Seminar since 1950.
Professor Perkins has engaged in numerous other civic and learned activities.
He was city historian of Rochester, New York, from 1936 to 1953. He was of¬
ficial Historian for the Overseas Branch of the Office of War Information at
the United Nations Conference in San Francisco in 19145. Among his other
activities, he is a moderator of the Unitarian Churches of the United States
and Canada, a member of the Association of University Professors, and a
member and President for 1956 of the American Historical Association.
Boro in Boston in 1889, Professor Perkins received his A,B. in 1909 and
Ph.D in I91I4, both from Harvard University. He is a member of Phi Beta Kappa,
and received a Litt.D, from Harvard in 1953 and a Ll.D from Union College ?
